moves.1. e4: I have already annotated how I lost a won position against this same opponent. So in the return match, I was out for blood!
moves.1... c5: So I played the Sicilian Defence, which usually offers both sides winning chances.
moves.2. Nc3: More common is Nf3. Nc6 is usually followed by a king's side fianchetto (g3 and Bg2) and a gradual build up on the king side.
moves.2... Nc6 3. Nf3 d6 4. d4: But now he has transposed back into main lines.
moves.4... cxd4 5. Nxd4 Nf6: The standard position in the Open Sicilian
moves.6. Bb5: But this is a bit unusual. 6. Bg5 is the most common move, followed by Bc4 and then Be2.
moves.6... Bd7: I play the most common reply
moves.7. O-O g6: This move seemed to score highly on the databases
moves.8. Re1 Bg7 9. Nf3: To me the white set-up is a little tame.
moves.9... O-O 10. Nd5: As played in Karklins, Andrew (2355) vs. Serper, Grigory (2535)  (which ended in a draw)
moves.10... Bg4 11. Bg5: In Karklins, Andrew (2355) vs. Serper, Grigory (2535)  11..... e6 was played. Maybe I should have followed it.....
I think this is where I had a major miscalculation. Simply Qc7 or maybe Qc8 (eyeing my weak white squares and maybe preparing a6 and/or e6 and I have a very sound position. An extra pawn, my errant queen has withdrawn from enemy territory. Instead I try and block the e file, but my queen is soon in trouble.
moves.23... Be5 24. Bc6 Rab8 25. Re4: and now there is a real danger that my queen will get caught without any squares to move to.
moves.25... Rdc8 26. Rc4 Rxc6: Of course white could now take my queen, but I would have rook, bishop and pawn for it, and every chance of saving the game. White correctly takes the exchange instead.
moves.27. dxc6 Qa5 28. a4 e6 29. Bf4 Qd5 30. Q: I was thinking I may be able to save this position - a pawn for the exchange is not too bad.....
moves.33... Ne7:
But 34. a5 is a clever stroke. Of course, if bxa5 
35. Rb8 Rxb8 
36. Rxb8+ Kg7 
37. c7 wins for white.
moves.34. a5 Rxc6 35. axb6 axb6 36. Rb5xb6 Rc5: I would like to keep rooks on, but I have to exchange or I just lose the d pawn
moves.38... Rxb5 39. Rxb5 Ne7: and once again he finds the best move! This move wins a pawn, but leaves 3 vs 3 on the kings side. There is still work to be done!
moves.40. c4 dxc4 41. Rxe5 Nf5 42. Rc5 Kg7: Of course, if Nd6, just Rc6
moves.43. Rxc4 g5 44. Kf1 Kg6 45. Ke2 f6 46. f: Of course, my king has to stay with the pawns - even if I find myself in a mating net!
moves.55... Kh5 56. Kf6 Nc3: Please let me play Nd5 check! or why not play Rd6 to stop the check, so I can play Ne4 check instead!
moves.57. Rb8 Ne4+ 58. Kg7 g4 59. Rb5+: Unfortunately I have only one move out of check
moves.59... Ng5 60. Kf6: and now he wins the rook and the game. So dear reader, what is your view? Obviously I made a big mistake in not bringing my queen to safety, but did I make other mistakes? Was I right to surrender the 2 bishops in an open position? Was it correct to go pawn grabbing with my queen? Over to you!
